attributes.title: Hasbro Faces Tough Sledding This Fourth Quarter
summary: Hasbro's business is heavily dependent on its movie support and this is not looking good this quarter.
In addition, more innovative newcomers are muscling into the company's market shares in the Action Figure, Fashion Doll, and Outdoor [Nerf] positions.
As a result, Hasbro is losing shelf space at the major brick-and-mortar retailers.
Even though the U.S. toy market is exceptionally strong this quarter, the current outlook for Hasbro promises to be again negative.

attributes.content:
It is an accepted fact that toy-related movies tend to drive the toy sales of the IPs depicted and that the bigger the box office of this movie is the bigger the retail sales of the toys are likely to be. This is still true today and Hasbro (NASDAQ:HAS) faces a rough fourth quarter as a consequence.

This is how the movie line-up looked for the fourth quarter last year and this year:

Source: Box Office Mojo and IGN Entertainment

This comparison suggests that at least in the U.S. the competitive advantage Hasbro had last year on the strength of its movie offering versus its competition is pretty much reversed this year. Whilst this comparison is applicable to the U.S. only - the world's largest toy market - all anecdotal evidence suggests that the picture will not be much different internationally.

The movie factor is important, but it is not the only one that negatively affects Hasbro's outlook for the quarter. The other factor is that new entrants are taking share away from the more established companies. (Incidentally, whilst this information will undoubtedly be redundant for most of my readers, the editors of Seeking Alpha insist that I explain how I get the data for the Klosters Retailer Panel quoted at the bottom of each of the chart above. It is derived from my proprietary U.S. retailer panel consisting of ten individual stores - one Walmart (WMT), one Target (TGT), one Barnes + Noble (BKS), one J. C. Penney (JCP), one Kohl's (KSS), one CVS, one Walgreens (WBA), and three Learning Express specialty stores. I will not provide any further identification given the confidential nature of the relationships.)

Again, in this instance, all evidence suggests that these trends are not unique to the U.S. toy market but are equally applicable worldwide.

The national buyers at the key brick-and-mortar retailers are clearly aware of this and have already adjusted their shelf space allocations to reflect this. In addition, they have moved to give space to promising newcomers at the expense of Hasbro and Mattel (MAT).

This shelf space picture represents the situation after the Holiday reset by both retailers after Halloween and is hence very unlikely to change between now and end of the year.

Toys"R"Us demise and its negative impact have not been mentioned once in this article for one simple reason - it is no longer a factor. The consumers have moved on, the remaining retailers have adjusted to the new reality, and the toy manufacturers that have adapted to the changed landscape are prospering.

Even though the U.S. toy market is growing strongly - on the basis of the trajectory seen during October and November and given the very good Thanksgiving and Cyber Monday performance - all indications are that this rising tide will not be enough to lift the Hasbro boat. Hasbro's sell-through in the U.S. during October and November has basically been down by approximately 5% and will remain so unless things change dramatically in December. All feedback from national buyers tells me that there is nothing on the horizon that could provide this dramatic change. Hasbro's 2017 fourth quarter performance was already pretty disappointing and 2018 does not promise much better as a result.

attributes.bio:
Lutz is an acknowledged expert on the toy space. His clients include one of the top three U.S. banks and one of the top three non-public toy companies worldwide. Between 1984 and 2002, Lutz was the CEO at five different manufacturing companies catering to U.S. and international mass retailers. He's lived on five continents and speaks six languages.


He started his business intelligence consulting practice in 2003 and he derives his information from three primary sources. The first is his proprietary retailer panel, which includes Wal-Mart, Target, J C Penney, Kohl's, Gamestop, Dollar General, Barnes + Noble and Learning Express. This panel provides him with sell-through data, shelf space changes, inventory levels and other pertinent metrics governing the major companies and products active in the two industry categories. The second is national buyers at 30 leading retailers in 17 large country markets. These provide color on trends and issues that have a bearing on the major manufacturers and products in the two industry categories. The last is mainly Chinese third-party manufacturers who provide insights into supply and inventory issues affecting the major companies or products in the two industry categories.

Lutz consults with banks and hedge funds, and hence does not trade in any stocks associated with companies active in the spaces he focuses on. Lutz also is a monthly contributor to Seeking Alpha. He also publishes a monthly Toy Newsletter, which can be found on his website, www.klosterstrading.com.
